docs.snippet: Few could have predicted last Sept. 15, at the start of the BOC yacht race around the world in Newport, R.I., how fast the leading single-handed sailboats would circle the globe.    Those who talked of breaking the 125-day barrier seemed daring. But...
docs.lead_paragraph: Few could have predicted last Sept. 15, at the start of the BOC yacht race around the world in Newport, R.I., how fast the leading single-handed sailboats would circle the globe. Those who talked of breaking the 125-day barrier seemed daring. But their estimates now seem conservative given the breakneck speed at which the top solo skippers are approaching the finish line in Newport after 27,000 miles at sea. With the first yachts expected to begin arriving Tuesday, an elapsed sailing time of 120 days, not counting rest stops along the way, seems likely.

headline.main: Global Speed Mark Likely to Be Broken

docs.snippet: Christophe Auguin, one of two French yachtsmen vying for first place in the BOC solo sailboat race around the world, crossed the finish line here this morning at 1:11 A.M. He was the first of 18 competitors to complete the 27,000-mile voyage.   Race...
docs.lead_paragraph: Christophe Auguin, one of two French yachtsmen vying for first place in the BOC solo sailboat race around the world, crossed the finish line here this morning at 1:11 A.M. He was the first of 18 competitors to complete the 27,000-mile voyage. Race officials said it was too soon to name an overall winner because of the close time difference between Auguin's 60-foot sailboat, Groupe Sceta, and Generali Concorde, a 60-foot yacht being sailed by Alain Gautier.

docs.snippet: The wait of a lifetime ended tonight for Christophe Auguin of France when officials for the 27,000-mile BOC solo race around the world named the 31-year-old yachtsman as the official winner of the competition.    The victory capped a race, already...
docs.lead_paragraph: The wait of a lifetime ended tonight for Christophe Auguin of France when officials for the 27,000-mile BOC solo race around the world named the 31-year-old yachtsman as the official winner of the competition. The victory capped a race, already marked by icebergs, whales, capsizings and even a suicide, that took a final dramatic turn today as one of the top two contenders stalled only 212 miles from the finish line.

headline.main: Sailing Around the World in 8 Months to Finish Neck and Neck

docs.snippet: SULTRY summer afternoons in the American South may be met with long icy glasses of tea laced with lemon or mint. Here in the heart of South America, Paraguay's answer to 100-degree heat is a centuries-old Indian refreshment.    For many here, the...
docs.lead_paragraph: SULTRY summer afternoons in the American South may be met with long icy glasses of tea laced with lemon or mint. Here in the heart of South America, Paraguay's answer to 100-degree heat is a centuries-old Indian refreshment. For many here, the early light of day is met with hot yerba mate. As the day progresses, businessmen and farm laborers alike stop to sip terere, a cool version of yerba mate. The drinking of hot or cold infusions of the native yerba plant is an intrinsic element in the everyday routine in both the country and the city.

headline.main: Yerba Mate, Ancient Antidote To South America's Heat

docs.snippet: The French solo sailor Alain Gautier, skipper of Generali Concorde whose ripped mainsail cost him a victory Tuesday in the BOC yacht race around the world, is expected to arrive here at about 7 A.M. Thursday in second place.   In a communique with...
docs.lead_paragraph: The French solo sailor Alain Gautier, skipper of Generali Concorde whose ripped mainsail cost him a victory Tuesday in the BOC yacht race around the world, is expected to arrive here at about 7 A.M. Thursday in second place. In a communique with his race office in Paris today, Gautier said he was very disappointed over losing the eight-month, 27,000-mile race to his friend Christophe Auguin.

docs.snippet: It seems inconceivable that the U.S. would deny itself the ability to negotiate the elimination of barriers to foreign trade. But that will happen if Congress derails the "fast track" authority for conducting trade negotiations.   Since 1974,...
docs.lead_paragraph: It seems inconceivable that the U.S. would deny itself the ability to negotiate the elimination of barriers to foreign trade. But that will happen if Congress derails the "fast track" authority for conducting trade negotiations. Since 1974, fast-track procedures have been an effective mechanism for approving trade agreements. They require the President to consult with Congress during trade negotiations and Congress to accept or reject the agreement, with no amendments, when it is submitted for approval.

docs.snippet: IS the world economy headed for a split into three warring trade blocs -- Europe, North America and East Asia?    "Not if we succeed in the Uruguay Round," said Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, during a discussion in New York...
docs.lead_paragraph: IS the world economy headed for a split into three warring trade blocs -- Europe, North America and East Asia? "Not if we succeed in the Uruguay Round," said Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, during a discussion in New York this week. Named for the country where the current trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade began in 1986, the Uruguay Round broke down in December over Europe's refusal to yield to American demands for drastic cuts in farm subsidies.

headline.main: Economic Scene; Trade Bloc War? Concern Grows

docs.snippet: Trade representatives met today to try to streamline negotiating procedures in the latest round of world trade talks that faltered in December.   A spokesman for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 108-nation world body governing the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Trade representatives met today to try to streamline negotiating procedures in the latest round of world trade talks that faltered in December. A spokesman for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 108-nation world body governing the talks, said a steering committee would meet in two months to approve changes in procedure.

docs.snippet: The Bush Administration, facing a critical vote in Congress next month over its authority to negotiate with other countries on trade, will make significant environmental and job-security commitments to accompany a trade pact with Mexico,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush Administration, facing a critical vote in Congress next month over its authority to negotiate with other countries on trade, will make significant environmental and job-security commitments to accompany a trade pact with Mexico, Administration and Congressional aides said today. The commitments are intended to sway votes in a battle that has pitted the Administration and proponents of free trade against organized labor, textile interests and others who fear that greater trade with Mexico will result in the loss of jobs and a weakening of environmental and labor standards.
